items.title: Orange Peel In Clear Coat? 2000 Grit Wet Sanding Steps
items.description: Orange peel in clear coat? Wet sand with 2000 grit to level texture before polishing. Keep the surface wet, use light pressure, crosshatch passes, wipe often, and check reflection under a work light. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Plastic Looks Dull? 2000 Grit Wet Sand For Gloss Prep
items.description: Plastic surface looks dull? Wet sand with 2000 grit to refine before polishing for a clearer gloss. Keep it wet, use light pressure, crosshatch passes, wipe clean often, and inspect under strong light for a consistent scratch pattern. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Which Grit To Start Wet Sanding? 800 vs 1000 Quick Guide
items.description: Which grit to start wet sanding—800 or 1000? Use 800 grit for heavier oxidation, deeper texture, or faster leveling; use 1000 grit for lighter defects and a softer cut. Keep it wet, use light pressure, and step up through finer grits. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Wet Sanding Leaves Scratches? Fix It With 1500 To 2000 Grit
items.description: Wet sanding still leaves scratches? The fix is grit progression: refine with 1500 grit first, then switch to 2000 grit to remove the 1500 scratch pattern before polishing. Keep it wet, use light pressure, and wipe often to inspect. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Wet Sanding Grit Guide: 800 To 3000 (When To Use Each)
items.description: Not sure which grit to use for wet sanding? Quick guide: 800 removes heavy defects, 1000–1500 refines, 2000 preps for polishing, 3000 is final polish prep. Keep it wet, use light pressure, and step up once the scratch pattern is uniform. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Wet Sanding Before Polishing: Use 2000 Grit For Polish Prep
items.description: Wet sanding before polishing? Use 2000 grit to refine the surface so polishing cuts faster and more evenly. Keep it wet, use light pressure, crosshatch passes, wipe clean often, and inspect under strong light for a consistent scratch pattern. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Still Rough After Wet Sanding? Step 1500 To 2000 Grit
items.description: Surface still rough after wet sanding? Step up: use 1500 grit to smooth and level, then 2000 grit to refine for a cleaner finish before polishing. Keep it wet, use light pressure, wipe often, and stop when the scratch pattern looks uniform. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: When To Use 3000 Grit Wet Sanding (Final Polish Prep)
items.description: When should you use 3000 grit wet sanding? Use it after 2000 grit when you want a finer finish before polishing—especially on clear coat and plastics. Keep it wet, use light pressure, crosshatch passes, and wipe often to inspect. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Wet Sanding Order Confusing? 800-1500-2000 Simple Steps
items.description: Wet sanding order confusing? Simple steps: 800 grit levels heavier defects, 1500 grit refines, 2000 grit preps for polishing. Keep it wet, use light pressure, and move up only when the scratch pattern is uniform. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Wet Sanding Too Aggressive? Move Up Grits For More Control
items.description: Wet sanding feels too aggressive? Move up to a finer grit and reduce pressure for more control. Use more water, shorten your passes, and step up gradually until the scratch pattern looks finer and more uniform. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Wet Sanding Takes Too Long? Use The Right Grit Progression
items.description: Wet sanding takes too long? The fix is proper grit progression: start only as coarse as needed, then step up in logical jumps so each grit removes the previous scratch pattern quickly. Keep it wet, use light pressure, and wipe often to inspect. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Want Better Polishing Results? Wet Sand 2000 Then 3000 Grit
items.description: Want better polishing results? Wet sand with 2000 grit to refine, then 3000 grit for final polish prep. Keep it wet, use light pressure, crosshatch passes, wipe clean often, and polish only after the scratch pattern looks uniform and fine. Wet or dry use. — eQualle
